awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Seismic imaging of volcano construction, underplating and flexure along the Hawaiian-Emperor Seamount Chain
awd_abstract_narration:
The Hawaii-Emperor Seamount Chain is the most well-known example on Earth of hotspot magmatism, where volcanoes form far from plate boundaries above hot regions in the underlying mantle. Many questions remain about the fundamental earth processes that create the volcanoes of the Hawaii-Emperor chain and elsewhere, and how the enormous mass of these volcanos is supported by the rock material below them.  This study will involve two seagoing expeditions to seismically image the magmatic crust created by the hotspot and obtain critical information about the crust's volume, its composition, how it varies along the island chain, and how the tectonic plate deforms in response to the weight of the volcanoes. In addition to gaining fundamental insight into the formation of the Hawaiian-Emperor chain, the study will also be beneficial to a more comprehensive assessment of geohazards for the Hawaiian island region.  Seismic data will image faults within the volcanic edifice and in the surrounding oceanic crust that can be used to evaluate seismic, tsunami and submarine landslide hazards. The project involves strong national and international collaborations. The research cruises will provide excellent opportunities to involve students in data acquisition and analysis, and the results will be the basis for a large public outreach and education effort.

The scientific objectives of the planned data acquisition and analysis of this project are to examine controls on magmatic addition along the Hawaiian-Emperor seamount chain, provide fundamental constraints on rheological properties of oceanic lithosphere, address the origin of the hotspot swell, and assess implications for earthquakes and tsunamis from plate deformation in response to flexure. The plan is to acquire coincident 2D, deep-penetration seismic reflection data as well as wide-angle reflection/refraction data using ocean bottom seismometers spaced at 15 km along four 500-km-long transects across the Hawaiian-Emperor seamount chain.  The locations of these transects will encompass wide variations in the timing of magma emplacement and volume flux, the age of the lithosphere at the time of loading and the presence/absence of a topographic swell. The transects are sufficiently long to capture the flexural response of the lithosphere to volcano loading out to the flexural bulge. The processed seismic reflection profiles and velocity models created from wide-angle seismic data will constrain the volume and distribution of magmatic addition to the crust as well as faulting within the volcanic edifice and within the loaded oceanic plate. New seismic constraints will be combined with gravity, magnetic, bathymetric and geochemical data and used as the basis for flexural analysis and numerical modeling to gain fundamental new insights into crust and lithosphere dynamics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Hawaii-Emperor Seamount Chain is the most well-known example on Earth of hotspot magmatism, where volcanoes form far from plate boundaries above hot regions in the underlying mantle. Many questions remained about the fundamental earth processes that create the volcanoes of the Hawaii-Emperor Seamount Chain and elsewhere, and how the enormous mass of these volcanos is supported by the rock material below them. To address these questions, this study involved two seagoing expeditions to seismically image the youngest portion of the chain around Hawaii and an older portion within the Emperor Chain, respectively.  The seismic images and velocity models produced from this project provided new information about the crust's volume, its composition, how it varies along the island chain, and how the Pacific oceanic plate flexes in response to the weight of the volcanoes.   Here are several highlights from this study: 1) We found that seamounts in both the Hawaii and Emperor parts of the chain have localized, mafic cores below major volcanoes surrounding by layers of lava and debris flows. These new constraints on the internal structure can be used to understand magmatic plumbing below seamounts. 2) Seismic data constrain the thickness and structure of the oceanic crust on which the Hawaii-Emperor Seamount Chain formed; furthermore, we were able to image the continuation of some major features in the oceanic plate farther below the seamount chain than was previously possible and assess their possible influence on the formation of seamount chain.  3)  We observe significant changes along the chain in the way that the Pacific oceanic plate flexes under the load of the seamounts, which we have used to understand controls on the strength of oceanic plates, including their age.

In addition to gaining fundamental insight into the formation of the Hawaii-Emperor Seamount Chain, this study also provided information relevant to geohazards for the Hawaiian island region. Seismic data imaged major faults systems, such as the contact between the volcanic edifice and the underlying plate; new constraints on the geometry and properties of these faults can be used to improve understanding of seismic hazards. We were also able to use the seismic data to constrain the volume and internal structure of a couple of major submarine landslides that flank the Hawaiian Islands and thus better understand how they form. 

The project facilitated strong national and international collaborations.  Project partners met regularly over zoom and in person at international meetings.  The project also provided excellent educational opportunities for early career scientists.  We brought 16 early career scientists from around the country to sea on the two expeditions through an apply-to-sail program. Participants told the PIs that they found the experience to be very valuable and important to their future careers.  The data produced by this project was the basis for multiple PhD and postdoc research projects.
